title: Race-winning Western Australian greyhound Miss Bondi tests positive for METH
text:
A race-winning greyhound has tested positive for ice but police won't be investigating as it is not illegal to feed the drug to dogs.

Amphetamine was found in a sample taken from Miss Bondi after the greyhound won a race in Mandurah, Western Australia in April.

Its trainer Robert Westworth was suspended but no criminal proceedings were ever brought against him.

A race-winning greyhound has tested positive for ice but police won't be investigating as it is not illegal to feed the drug to dogs (stock image)

Addressing the case this week, the state's Labor leader in the Upper House said industry authorities were not compelled to tell police about positive tests.

'The detection of a prohibited substance in a racing animal is not considered a criminal offence,' she said according to parliament documents seen by Daily Mail Australia.

'Therefore there are no police resources dedicated to racing matters.'

She added 35 per cent of winning horses - totalling 1,229 swabs - were tested last year for prohibited substances at a racing event.

Only 0.05 per cent came back positive for prohibited substances.

She said the jurisdiction for testing racing dogs for drugs was laid out in section 45 of the Racing and Wagering Western Australia Act 2003.

Greens Legislative Council member Alison Xamon hit out at the law, saying the drugging of dogs was a 'clearly unacceptable cruel act'.

Amphetamine was found in a sample taken from Miss Bondi after the greyhound won a race in Mandurah, Western Australia in April (stock image of an amphetamine)

'I note individuals caught in the cycle of genuine drug addiction find themselves feeling the full brunt of the law. They are not shown the same sort of leniency,' she said.

'Why should people who are associated with the greyhound industry be treated any differently?

'If it (Racing and Wagering WA) is finding illicit substances in its dogs, referral to the police should absolutely be an automatic step.'

The inquiry into Mr Westworth's suspension has been delayed from its original date in September pending further evidence.
